item.title: Governing the Commons - Elinor Ostrom

item.title: The Making of the Tech Worker Movement
item.description: Software engineers, product designers, and others enjoyed better conditions than most workers, but they were still workers. A select few would even ascend into upper management or acquire enough capital to become truly bourgeois. But most would remain in the middle layers, and among the proletarian aspects of this location was the exclusion from real decision-making—namely, investment and production decisions such as whether to build a piece of software for the Trump Administration.

item.title: This Drug Can Mend a Broken Heart
item.description: “Memory reconsolidation” describes how, when we recall a memory, it can become pliable. There is hope—and some intriguing early data—that, at the moment of recollection, we might be able to intentionally change a memory and make it less burdensome. This ability to modulate distressing memories is being investigated as an intervention to treat post-traumatic stress disorder,1 addiction,2 phobias,3 and is thought to have promise for depression or anxiety more broadly. It rests on an idea that’s emerged from our understanding of memory over the past few decades: Memories are not fixed, even the ones that haunt us the most.

item.title: Unions - Scale and Trust
item.description: As global supply chains have become more distributed since the mid-1990s due to international tariff and trade normalization, conglomerations of firms have been moving away from largely centralized enterprises – those that firm-oriented or trade-specific unions have traditionally been structured around – by shifting activities into component parts, distributed in such a way so as to gain comparative cost advantages in local material and labor markets. The new shape of production is therefore more of a diffuse, global network of firms, national regulatory contexts, and markets containing many and varied forms workers that fall through the cracks of union structures.

item.title: Unions Can Beat Anti-Labor Politicians
item.description: For the Ford administration, the demands of the education workers were not just about one subsector but a Trojan horse for gains across the public sector. The dilemma for the union was that in spite of the conflict’s significance for the entire public sector (and less directly, for private sector bargaining), the battle was being led and fought by only a subsector of the union movement.

item.title: Why a Messaging App Meant for Festivals Became Massively Popular During Hong Kong Protests
item.description: Unlike WhatsApp and other messaging apps, FireChat doesn’t require an internet connection for users to communicate. Instead, it uses a phone’s Bluetooth and Wi-Fi signals to connect it to other devices within a given range. In this setup, known as a mesh network , each phone acts as a node, and as more devices link together, the network’s range expands. Users can send texts and images under pseudonyms — another benefit for government-fearing protesters — though Open Garden recently introduced verified accounts for some journalists.
